{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3329027,"name":"blturner","username":"blturner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/blturner/{size}/70462_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-10T15:13:57.332Z","cooked":"

We changed our code to turn to the calculated angle from Photonvision to avoid low frame rates from causing us to overshoot when feeding the vision produced angle into the turn pid. It is working well but introduces a new problem. Because the camera is tilted back at 20 degrees the height reported is lower/higher the further it is from straight ahead. I believe this is due to parallax. Would turning on 3D processing fix this without hurting frame rate too much? Or should we just use a formula to correct for the error. We are using a Lifecam.
I think the formula would be something like sin(abs(angleerror)*30 where 30 is a factor that we tune. I was planning on feeding this result into the target height. But I don’t know if I can ignore the distance. We are using Java but I think the math would be the same for any language.

blturner:

Would turning on 3D processing fix this without hurting frame rate too much?

My suggestion would be to try it and see. You can do some tuning of your input resolution, exposure and brightness, or your pipeline to try to reduce latency.

I think we are going to try and switch to aiming from pose information. That will not have this issue and will let us shoot when the april tag is blocked by a defender.

In case others find this thread, we found that our camera mount would shift by a few degrees if bumped and that may have been the whole problem. This parallax stuff might be barking up the wrong tree, but I don’t know.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T14:13:26.639Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":61,"readers_count":60,"score":12.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":458130,"topic_slug":"vision-height-error-correction","display_username":"blturner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16837,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/vision-height-error-correction/458130/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335153,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T15:28:43.713Z","cooked":"

I think I understand the original weakness in your control system that you corrected but I don’t understand the relationship with height and a shifting mount. In general you want to get the angle to turn to from the vision and use that as a setpoint for your drive motor-gyro PID control. As you get new values at a slow rate from vision you feed them as setpoints to the high speed feedback PID of the drive motor-gyro system. This is robust from some position errors that occur when far from the target angle and the errors diminish as the robot to target becomes well-aimed. You should keep updating the high-speed system with new, better information from the low speed system and they merge when on target.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T15:28:43.713Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":47,"readers_count":46,"score":14.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":458130,"topic_slug":"vision-height-error-correction","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/vision-height-error-correction/458130/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335293,"name":"blturner","username":"blturner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/blturner/{size}/70462_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T19:36:10.168Z","cooked":"

Yes, The camera updates (in our case) 17 times a second and our control loop is going at 20 ms or 50 times a second. That makes the latency vary with the difference between the two. I know that the software has the ability to time tag the data with a timestamp or a latency but I don’t know how to even ask my programmer to use that. So I do believe that what you describe is the best way to do it, but I don’t know the answers to the other questions that it raises for things like variable latency causing the calculation of the D of the PID to jump. Should I slow the control loop to match the camera? We now have a faster camera and coprocessor, so that we should get 30+ times a second and I think all of this shrinks to not mattering.
As to the camera angle shifting the distance to the target in Photonvision seems to be calculated based on the trig of the height vs angle. It knows that a pixel is so many degrees and that the camera is aimed upward at 18 degrees so the angle to the target is known. The height of the target from the ground is also known as is the height of the camera. That makes the distance from the camera to goal a simple trig calculation. What I was suspecting was that the height of a pixel in degrees varied with the left right position in the cameras field of view. I can’t prove or disprove that. I did find that problem many years back when doing vision on the RIO. YMMV

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T19:36:10.168Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":35,"readers_count":34,"score":12.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":458130,"topic_slug":"vision-height-error-correction","display_username":"blturner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24594,"username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16837,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/vision-height-error-correction/458130/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335349,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T20:54:44.050Z","cooked":"

It sounds like you are trying for a much more sophisticated control system than my team uses. We keep it very simple as I described in my previous post and only use the P of a PID and do have a tolerance for arriving near the setpoint. I admit there are complaints about how fast it settles but by my eye it has settled way before the actual shot is taken so the students are trying to track down the delay this week.

I can’t see how slowing a PID loop to match the setpoint update loop could help much. If you want some hints on handling latency I’d try looking at the WPILib poseEstimator that we use for the swerve drive. It uses the InterpolatingTreeMap and more to get time-stamped values that don’t exist.

There are other strategies that can be used in various combinations.

Don’t use the proportional zone for the entire deviation from the goal. At the edges full speed ahead until closer to the goal then kick in the P.

Don’t control to a tolerance (that seems passé now with its removal from 3rd party motor controllers). Head for the setpoint and shoot as you cross it.

I had not heard of problems with the PhotonVision height calculation. If you think there is a problem then tag your thread with PhotonVision and likely a PV guru will respond. I couldn’t find your concern in the PV Discord and I think it’s the lack of the proper tag when you created the topic.
